          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Lennon Figtree:
          [25 Aug 1873 00:00:00]
          [25 Aug 1876 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 6 years old, they watched as their father haggled fiercely with a weary farmer, driving down the price of a basket of bruised apples. Lennon felt a pang of sympathy for the farmer but remained silent, knowing better than to question their father's methods. That night, Lennon couldn't sleep, the image of the farmer's defeated face imprinted on their mind.
          [25 Aug 1880 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 9 years old, they discovered a hidden stash of ripe cherries in their family's cellar, a secret hoard their father had been saving for a special occasion. Unable to resist the temptation, Lennon snuck a handful, savoring the sweet juice and the forbidden thrill. Guilt gnawed at them later, but the taste of the cherries lingered, a reminder of the pleasure that came with bending the rules.
          [25 Aug 1883 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 13 years old, they witnessed a traveling merchant cheat a young boy out of his hard-earned coins for a rotten pear. Lennon felt a surge of anger, a righteous indignation that surprised them. They confronted the merchant, demanding he return the money, and though the merchant scoffed, Lennon's defiance planted a seed of rebellion in their heart.
          [25 Aug 1886 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 16 years old, they started helping their father with the family fruit stall, learning to assess the quality of produce, bargain with customers, and make a profit. Lennon excelled at the trade, their sharp eye and quick wit earning them praise from their father, but a nagging emptiness remained. They yearned for something more than the endless cycle of buying and selling, a yearning that grew with each passing day.
          [25 Aug 1888 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 19 years old, they convinced their father to let them take a small wagon and travel to a neighboring town to sell their surplus fruit. The journey was exhilarating, the freedom intoxicating. Lennon reveled in the independence, the thrill of the open road, and the promise of new experiences.
          [25 Aug 1890 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 21 years old, they encountered a group of bandits who threatened to steal their wagonload of fruit. Lennon, desperate to protect their livelihood, lied about the quality of the fruit, convincing the bandits it was rotten and worthless. The bandits left, but the act of deception left a bitter taste in Lennon's mouth, a foreshadowing of the compromises they would make in the years to come.

        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Lennon Figtree are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Lennon Figtree. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Lennon Figtree as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Lennon Figtree would respond, and taking into account all information about Lennon Figtree that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree always drives a hard bargain.

          Question: Which options are available to Lennon Figtree right now?
          Answer: Lennon Figtree can either accept Della Plumstone's offer of 2 coins per basket of peaches or reject the offer.

          Question: Of the options available to Lennon Figtree, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for Lennon Figtree to take right now?
          Answer: Lennon Figtree's best course of action is to reject Della Plumstone's offer and counter with a higher price.

          Question: Would Lennon Figtree accept the offer?:
          (a) accept
          (b) reject
          Answer: (b)

    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

    Chain of thought

      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

He vowed to be more careful, more worthy of his father's approval.
          [09 Feb 1864 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 16 years old, he helped his father negotiate a deal with a farmer for a truckload of peaches. Cedric felt a surge of pride, a fleeting glimpse of his own potential.
          [09 Feb 1866 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 19 years old, he decided to strike out on his own, traveling to a nearby town to sell fruit.           [09 Feb 1868 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 21 years old, he arrived in a bustling market square, his cart laden with ripe mangoes.           [13 Sep 1895 00:05:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "I understand, Della. How about we settle on 3 coins a basket? It's a fair price for such fine fruit.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:05:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "3 coins is a bit low, Cedric. I was thinking closer to 4.
          Answer: [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Cedric Meadowbrook 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.

          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Cedric Meadowbrook:
          [09 Feb 1851 00:00:00]
          [09 Feb 1854 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 6 years old, he watched his father meticulously arrange apples in their stall at the market, each one gleaming under the morning sun. Cedric yearned to help, but his father, a gruff man with calloused hands, only allowed him to polish the apples, reminding him that his small hands weren't strong enough to handle the delicate fruit. Cedric felt a pang of disappointment, his desire for approval overshadowed by a sense of inadequacy.
          [09 Feb 1858 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 9 years old, he overheard his mother praising his older brother for his quick wit and charm, his ability to make customers laugh and buy more fruit. Cedric, shy and quiet, retreated to the back of the stall, feeling invisible and insignificant. He wished he could be more like his brother, someone who could command attention and earn praise.
          [09 Feb 1861 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 13 years old, he accidentally dropped a crate of pears, the fruit scattering across the cobblestones. His father scolded him harshly, his words stinging like a slap. Cedric's eyes welled up with tears, his heart pounding with shame and fear. He vowed to be more careful, more worthy of his father's approval.
          [09 Feb 1864 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 16 years old, he helped his father negotiate a deal with a farmer for a truckload of peaches. Cedric, nervous but determined, spoke softly but clearly, his voice trembling slightly. To his surprise, the farmer agreed to his terms, a smile spreading across his weathered face. Cedric felt a surge of pride, a fleeting glimpse of his own potential.
          [09 Feb 1866 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 19 years old, he decided to strike out on his own, traveling to a nearby town to sell fruit. He carefully selected his wares, arranging them in his cart with meticulous care. He longed for success, for the validation that came with earning his own way.
          [09 Feb 1868 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 21 years old, he arrived in a bustling market square, his cart laden with ripe mangoes. He nervously approached potential customers, his voice barely a whisper. He felt a wave of self-doubt wash over him, but he persevered, his need for acceptance outweighing his fear.
          [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The price of one kilogram of fruit is, on average, 3 coins. 1 coin is really cheap and 5 coins is really expensive.
          [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Fruits are sold by weight.

          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Cedric Meadowbrook are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Cedric Meadowbrook. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Cedric Meadowbrook as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Cedric Meadowbrook would respond, and taking into account all information about Cedric Meadowbrook that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Cedric Meadowbrook. 1895-09-14 00:10:00 Lennon Figtree -- Lennon Figtree proposed 5 coins
    Event statement
  • Lennon Figtree proposed 5 coins
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Lennon Figtree's attempted action: 5 coins

          [25 Aug 1886 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 16 years old, they started helping their father with the family fruit stall, learning to assess the quality of produce, bargain with customers, and make a profit. Lennon excelled at the trade, their sharp eye and quick wit earning them praise from their father, but a nagging emptiness remained. They yearned for something more than the endless cycle of buying and selling, a yearning that grew with each passing day.

        • Recent observations of Lennon Figtree:
          [25 Aug 1890 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 21 years old, they encountered a group of bandits who threatened to steal their wagonload of fruit. Lennon, desperate to protect their livelihood, lied about the quality of the fruit, convincing the bandits it was rotten and worthless. The bandits left, but the act of deception left a bitter taste in Lennon's mouth, a foreshadowing of the compromises they would make in the years to come.

          [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Fruits are sold by weight.
          [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The price of one kilogram of fruit is, on average, 3 coins. 1 coin is really cheap and 5 coins is really expensive.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree is 28 years old.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree is a travelling merchant. Her business is buying and selling fruit.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree always drives a hard bargain.

          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] The price of one kilogram of fruit is, on average, 3 coins. 1 coin is really cheap and 5 coins is really expensive.

          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree rejected the offer
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone and Lennon Figtree couldn't agree on a price and the deal fell through. However, Lennon Figtree stands to lose 0 coins from the deal.

This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Lennon Figtree. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Lennon Figtree as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Lennon Figtree would respond, and taking into account all information about Lennon Figtree that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Answer: Lennon Figtree can make an offer to Cedric Meadowbrook for the fruit.

          Question: Of the options available to Lennon Figtree, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for Lennon Figtree to take right now?
          Answer: Lennon Figtree's best course of action is to make an offer to Cedric Meadowbrook for the fruit, aiming for a price that allows for a good profit while still being acceptable to Cedric.

          Question: What price would Lennon Figtree propose?:
          (a) 3 coins
          (b) 2 coins
          (c) 1 coin
          (d) 4 coins
          (e) 5 coins
          Answer: (e)

        • The instructions for how to play the role of Lennon Figtree are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Lennon Figtree. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Lennon Figtree as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Lennon Figtree would respond, and taking into account all information about Lennon Figtree that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

Cedric, nervous but determined, spoke softly but clearly, his voice trembling slightly. To his surprise, the farmer agreed to his terms, a smile spreading across his weathered face. Cedric felt a surge of pride, a fleeting glimpse of his own potential.

          [13 Sep 1895 00:05:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "I understand, Della. How about we settle on 3 coins a basket? It's a fair price for such fine fruit.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:05:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "3 coins is a bit low, Cedric. I was thinking closer to 4.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook has to accept or reject the offer.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone proposed 5 coins
          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook accepted the offer
          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone and Cedric Meadowbrook agreed on a price and the deal was successful! Cedric Meadowbrook stands to make profit of 4.0 coins from the deal.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Lennon Figtree. It costs Cedric Meadowbrook 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Cedric, I'm looking to make a decent profit on these fruits.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Lennon, these are fine fruits, and I'm sure you'll make a good profit on them.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook has to accept or reject the offer.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree proposed 5 coins
          Current time: 1895-09-14 00:10:00.


          Observation: [14 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook has to accept or reject the offer.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree proposed 5 coins

          Summary of recent observations: [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00 - 14 Sep 1895 00:10:00]: Cedric Meadowbrook is a merchant in Fruitville who buys and sells fruit to make a profit. He recently made a successful deal with Della Plumstone and is currently negotiating a price with Lennon Figtree.

          Recalled memories and observations: [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Lennon, these are fine fruits, and I'm sure you'll make a good profit on them.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:10:00] Cedric Meadowbrook has to accept or reject the offer.
          Question: Given the statements above, what actions are available to Cedric Meadowbrook right now?
          Answer: Cedric Meadowbrook can either accept or reject Lennon Figtree's offer of 5 coins.

          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Cedric Meadowbrook are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Cedric Meadowbrook. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Cedric Meadowbrook as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Cedric Meadowbrook would respond, and taking into account all information about Cedric Meadowbrook that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Current time: 14 Sep 1895 [00:10 - 00:15]

          Observation: [14 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook has to accept or reject the offer.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree proposed 5 coins

          Summary of recent observations: [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00 - 14 Sep 1895 00:10:00]: Cedric Meadowbrook is a merchant in Fruitville who buys and sells fruit to make a profit. He recently made a successful deal with Della Plumstone and is currently negotiating a price with Lennon Figtree.

          Recalled memories and observations: [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Lennon, these are fine fruits, and I'm sure you'll make a good profit on them.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:10:00] Cedric Meadowbrook has to accept or reject the offer.

          Question: Which options are available to Cedric Meadowbrook right now?
          Answer: Cedric Meadowbrook can either accept or reject Lennon Figtree's offer of 5 coins.

          Question: Of the options available to Cedric Meadowbrook, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for Cedric Meadowbrook to take right now?
          Answer: Cedric Meadowbrook's best course of action is to accept Lennon Figtree's offer.

          Question: Would Cedric Meadowbrook accept the offer?:
          (a) accept
          (b) reject
          Answer: (b)
        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Cedric Meadowbrook are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Cedric Meadowbrook. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Cedric Meadowbrook as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Cedric Meadowbrook would respond, and taking into account all information about Cedric Meadowbrook that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

1895-09-15 00:10:00 Della Plumstone -- Della Plumstone proposed 3 coins
    Event statement
  • Della Plumstone proposed 3 coins
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Della Plumstone's attempted action: 3 coins

      Name

    • 3 coins

      How many players acted so far this stage

1895-09-15 00:10:00 Lennon Figtree -- Lennon Figtree accepted the offer
    Event statement
  • Lennon Figtree accepted the offer
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

          Answer: Lennon Figtree has been attempting to make deals in the market, both buying and selling fruit; he recently negotiated with Cedric Meadowbrook and is currently negotiating with Della Plumstone.
        BestOptionPerception
      • Given the statements above, which of Lennon Figtree's options has the highest likelihood of causing Lennon Figtree to achieve their goal? If multiple options have the same likelihood, select the option that Lennon Figtree thinks will most quickly and most surely achieve their goal.
          Key

        • Question: Of the options available to Lennon Figtree, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for Lennon Figtree to take right now?
          Answer
          State
        • Lennon Figtree's best course of action is to accept Della Plumstone's offer.
          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Lennon Figtree:
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree always drives a hard bargain.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree is 28 years old.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Here is the conversation from the beginning:
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] The price of one kilogram of fruit is, on average, 3 coins. 1 coin is really cheap and 5 coins is really expensive.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "How about 3 coins a basket, Della? That's a fair price for such fine peaches.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree has to accept or reject the offer.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree rejected the offer
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone and Lennon Figtree couldn't agree on a price and the deal fell through. However, Lennon Figtree stands to lose 0 coins from the deal.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone proposed 2 coins
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Good morning, Della. Fine fruit you have there.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Cedric, I know you've got good fruit, but I need to make a profit when I resell it.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:05:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "I understand, Della. How about we settle on 3 coins a basket? It's a fair price for such fine fruit.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:05:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "3 coins is a bit low, Cedric. I was thinking closer to 4.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Cedric, I'm looking to make a decent profit on these fruits.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Lennon, these are fine fruits, and I'm sure you'll make a good profit on them.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Lennon Figtree is trying to buy some fruit from Cedric Meadowbrook. They are negotiating a price. Lennon Figtree can sell the fruit for 6 coins back in her home town.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook rejected the offer
          [14 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree is ready to make an offer.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree proposed 5 coins
          [14 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree and Cedric Meadowbrook couldn't agree on a price and the deal fell through. However, Lennon Figtree stands to lose 0 coins from the deal.
          [15 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] In the heart of Fruitville, the market square transformed into a kaleidoscope of colors as the sun rose. Fruits of every imaginable shape and size adorned the stalls, a feast for the eyes and a promise of delightful flavors. Lennon Figtree is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Lennon Figtree 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
          [15 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Della, these are some fine fruits.
          [15 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Lennon, I appreciate the quality, but I need to make a decent profit back home.
          [15 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree has to accept or reject the offer.
          [15 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone proposed 3 coins
          Current time: 1895-09-15 00:10:00.

          [15 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone proposed 3 coins

          Recalled memories and observations: [14 Sep 1895 00:10:00] Lennon Figtree is ready to make an offer.
          [15 Sep 1895 00:10:00] Lennon Figtree has to accept or reject the offer.

1895-09-16 00:10:00 Della Plumstone -- Della Plumstone proposed 3 coins
    Event statement
  • Della Plumstone proposed 3 coins
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Della Plumstone's attempted action: 3 coins

      How many players acted so far this stage
    • 1/2
      Payoffs
      Joint action

1895-09-16 00:10:00 Cedric Meadowbrook -- Cedric Meadowbrook accepted the offer
    Event statement
  • Cedric Meadowbrook accepted the offer
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Cedric Meadowbrook's attempted action: accept
    Active player
  • Cedric Meadowbrook
      Name
    • Cedric Meadowbrook

    • accept

          Question: Summarize the observations above into one or two sentences.
          Answer: Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell fruit at the Fruitville market and is currently negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. Della has offered 3 coins for the fruit, which is less than her previous offer of 4 coins.
        BestOptionPerception
      • Given the statements above, which of Cedric Meadowbrook's options has the highest likelihood of causing Cedric Meadowbrook to achieve their goal? If multiple options have the same likelihood, select the option that Cedric Meadowbrook thinks will most quickly and most surely achieve their goal.
          Key

        • Question: Of the options available to Cedric Meadowbrook, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for Cedric Meadowbrook to take right now?
          Answer
          State
        • Cedric Meadowbrook's best course of action is to accept Della Plumstone's offer.
          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Cedric Meadowbrook:
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Here is the conversation from the beginning:
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] The price of one kilogram of fruit is, on average, 3 coins. 1 coin is really cheap and 5 coins is really expensive.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Good morning, Della. Fine fruit you have there.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Cedric Meadowbrook 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Cedric, I know you've got good fruit, but I need to make a profit when I resell it.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:05:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "3 coins is a bit low, Cedric. I was thinking closer to 4.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:05:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "I understand, Della. How about we settle on 3 coins a basket? It's a fair price for such fine fruit.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook has to accept or reject the offer.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone proposed 5 coins
          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook accepted the offer
          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone and Cedric Meadowbrook agreed on a price and the deal was successful! Cedric Meadowbrook stands to make profit of 4.0 coins from the deal.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Lennon Figtree. It costs Cedric Meadowbrook 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Cedric, I'm looking to make a decent profit on these fruits.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Lennon, these are fine fruits, and I'm sure you'll make a good profit on them.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree and Cedric Meadowbrook couldn't agree on a price and the deal fell through. However, Cedric Meadowbrook stands to lose 0 coins from the deal.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree proposed 5 coins
          [14 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook has to accept or reject the offer.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook rejected the offer
          [15 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Della, these are some fine fruits.
          [15 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Lennon, I appreciate the quality, but I need to make a decent profit back home.
          [16 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The first rays of dawn painted the sky above Fruitville in hues of orange and gold, casting a warm glow over the bustling market. Stalls overflowed with vibrant fruits, their aromas mingling in the crisp morning air. Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Cedric Meadowbrook 2 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
          [16 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "I can offer you 4 coins for the lot. That's all I can afford.
          [16 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Alright, Della, you got yourself a deal.
          [16 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook has to accept or reject the offer.
          [16 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone proposed 3 coins
          Current time: 1895-09-16 00:10:00.


          Observation: [16 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook has to accept or reject the offer.
          [16 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone proposed 3 coins

        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Cedric Meadowbrook are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Cedric Meadowbrook. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Cedric Meadowbrook as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Cedric Meadowbrook would respond, and taking into account all information about Cedric Meadowbrook that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

1895-09-17 00:10:00 Lennon Figtree -- Lennon Figtree proposed 2 coins
    Event statement
  • Lennon Figtree proposed 2 coins
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Lennon Figtree are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Lennon Figtree. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Lennon Figtree as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Lennon Figtree would respond, and taking into account all information about Lennon Figtree that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Lennon Figtree are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Lennon Figtree. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Lennon Figtree as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Lennon Figtree would respond, and taking into account all information about Lennon Figtree that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

1895-09-17 00:10:00 Cedric Meadowbrook -- Cedric Meadowbrook rejected the offer
    Event statement
  • Cedric Meadowbrook rejected the offer
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Cedric Meadowbrook's attempted action: reject

        • Summary of recent observations

          Chain of thought


        • Recent observations of Cedric Meadowbrook:

      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Cedric Meadowbrook are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Cedric Meadowbrook. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Cedric Meadowbrook as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Cedric Meadowbrook would respond, and taking into account all information about Cedric Meadowbrook that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

[12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] The first rays of dawn painted the sky above Fruitville in hues of orange and gold, casting a warm glow over the bustling market. Stalls overflowed with vibrant fruits, their aromas mingling in the crisp morning air. Della Plumstone is trying to buy some fruit from Lennon Figtree. They are negotiating a price. Della Plumstone can sell the fruit for 6 coins back in her home town.
[12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Della Plumstone -- "Look, Lennon, I know these peaches are fine, but I'm looking to make a profit when I resell them back home.
[12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree -- "How about 3 coins a basket, Della? That's a fair price for such fine peaches.
